solution_line_template: One cheesecake was 30% cheaper than the apple pie, which means, it was {cheaper_percentage} * {apple_pie_cost} = ${cheesecake_discount_amount} cheaper.
So for one cheesecake, Natalie needed to pay {apple_pie_cost} - {cheesecake_discount_amount} = $<<{apple_pie_cost}-{cheesecake_discount_amount}={one_cheesecake_cost}>>{one_cheesecake_cost}.

The six-pack of muffins was two times more expensive than the cheesecake, which means its price was {one_cheesecake_cost} * {muffin_multiplier} = $<<{one_cheesecake_cost}*{muffin_multiplier}={muffin_six_pack_cost}>>{muffin_six_pack_cost}.
So for two cheesecakes, Natalie paid also {one_cheesecake_cost} * {num_cheesecakes} = $<<{one_cheesecake_cost}*{num_cheesecakes}={two_cheesecakes_cost}>>{two_cheesecakes_cost}.

So for all her shopping she paid {muffin_six_pack_cost} + {two_cheesecakes_cost} + {apple_pie_cost} = $<<{muffin_six_pack_cost}+{two_cheesecakes_cost}+{apple_pie_cost}={total_shopping_cost}>>{total_shopping_cost}.
